div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, February 11, 1901
div1.p:
It is with the utmost embarrassment
that we venture to intrude upon the scien-
tific ecstasies of the Pan-American Medi-
cal Congress at Havana with a word or
two of tabloid thought. (Apologies to Mr.
Harmsworth.)

We have long watched the yellow fever
investigations of our authorities in Cuba
with almost breathless interest. Even
before our military occupation, January
1, 1899, Gen. Leonard Wood, then com-
manding the province of Santiago, with
headquarters at the city of that name,
had inaugurated a systematic inquiry into
the causes, conditions, character, and
cure of the disease. At first, he thought
the problem simple enough. A medical
man himself, and well up in his profes-
sion, he proceeded with no little con-
fidence. Here was a particularly dirty
town. Here also was yellow fever. Ergo:
Remove the dirt and the fever disappears.
In the summer of 1899, Gen. Wood went
to Boston on leave, and in the course of
some remarks to his admiring fellow-
citizens he stated that yellow fever had
been eradicated by the easy and obvious
expedient of destroying the material upon
which it depended for its vitality. In
other words, Santiago had been swept,
scrubbed, garnished, &c., and yellow fever
had therefore disappeared for good. Two
days after, Gen. Wood sailed for Santiago,
having been urgently recalled by an out-
break of yellow fever in epidemic form
at that post.

Gen. Wood does not now believe that
yellow fever can be extinguished by
means of street sweepers, shovels, and
carbolic acid.

Havana, also, was taken in hand, early
in 1899, and brushed and swept and filled
with acrid smells, for the purpose of ob-
literating the dreaded malady. A great
many thousands of dollars were expended
in the conduct of this interesting comedy,
and at one time it was triumphantly an-
nounced on high military and scientific
authority that the money had been benef-
icently spent, since yellow fever was no
more. The disease, however, went play-
fully along upon its accustomed way, just
as though such things as syringes, dust-
pans, brooms, &c., had never been heard
of in the world. Then the bubble burst,
and science began to look in new direc-
tions.

This brings us around to the Pan-Amer-
ican Medicals. These gentlemen have
given up the Sanarelli germs as unreli-
able. They have even turned a deaf ear
to Dr. Doty, the great New York expert,
who once made a number of important
discoveries by inoculating an invalid dray
horse and obtaining barrels upon barrels
of serum. He went so far, indeed, as to
procure a yellow fever patient and treat
him with great vigor. We have been as-
sured that he would have cured that pa-
tient if only he had had yellow fever. Dr.
Doty, however, still has the serum. But,
as we were saying, the Pan-American
Medicals have discarded all these fal-
lacies, They now solemnly announce that
“the specific cause of the disease is un-
known.” They also state that it is “not
due to dirt”--something the yellow fever
specialists of the South have insisted on
for the past sixty years. But they do
say that this disease, the origin of which
they cannot specify, is transmitted only
by mosquitoes. There has been some af-
fectionate wrangling on this point, one
side contending that all mosquitoes can
communicate the poison, while the others
maintain with great valor and determina-
tion that only the gray-legged variety is
gifted in the premises. But all are agreed
that the mosquito does the business, and
we must branch out from that.

Meanwhile, we should like to offer the
suggestion that since this controversy
has been finally settled the yellow fever
board and the Pan-American Medicals
generally can well afford to cease their
experiments upon inoffensive persons. One
member of the board has already died of
yellow fever, presumably as a result of
mosquito inoculation, and that ought to
be enough for all scientific purposes. Yel-
low fever is not the kind of disease that
can be passed around very fluently with-
out unpleasant consequences, and if these
gifted scientists are now convinced that
the mosquito is the real and only medium
of infection, why not devote themselves
to the eradication of the medium instead
of killing more people by way of aca-
demic demonstration?
